ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: NA

This was the first year that this course was merged. I wanted to share my feedback separately for each course.Mike Ferucci's operations course: I thought overall the course was really useful and the readings, field trips, and exercises were well planned and designed. Mike is really good at explaining material, and very responsive to student feedback.Chad Oliver's Managing Resources course: I thought this part of the course was pretty disappointing overall. I found the lectures very difficult to follow, almost incoherent, and the readings were similarly vague and mostly repetitive. The exercises were frustrating and time consuming and I heard nothing but negative feedback from my fellow classmates on each and every one of them. The final exam is similarly just a series of really vague and open ended questions that really don't teach anything tangible. The only redeeming quality about this class is that Chad is very flexible in terms of allowing students to design their own project and he is also very flexible with deadlines.I think it is a mistake to have joined these two courses, and I think people who want to learn more about forestry operations are much better suited taking a separate class with Mike. I found the Managing Resources section to be one of the most frustrating classes I've had at FES. If I could get a refund, I would.
Mike Ferrucci's portion of the course was great, but he was only given limited time. The following comments (except #14) are in relation to Oliver's portion of the course.

The entire course was extremely disjointed without any structure. There seemed to be minimal linkage between the Operations section taught by Professor Ferrucci and the other material presented by Professor Oliver.I walked away from the course with very, very, little benefit.

This is really two separate courses- the management course taught by Dr. Oliver and the operations component taught by Mike Ferrucci. The management component was poorly taught, did not follow any logical path, and was a significant waste of time. The operations component was okay, but still did not cover some important elements of practical forestry, such as contracting, monitoring logging jobs, log marketing, tallying, etc. These would be very good additions. If I hear another lecture about feller bunchers and forwarders I'm going to fall asleep.
The course improved my understanding of resource management global perspective.
class was an inappropriate combination of two materials - logging operations and general resource management
To all questions: these are evaluations of Chad Oliver. Mike Ferrucci's portion of the class was very valuable. I feel cheated that I did not get to take his full course.
Mike Ferucci gave good lectures. I don't know if I learned a single thing from Chad Oliver.

1--Not really any assigned readings. Just some documents thrown up on the class website. Never read anything2,3,4--The material taught in the class had no relation to the Exercises so going to lecture seemed completely pointless. The pace was slow because the lectures were illogical and seemed to contain no content. Some exercises required dozens of hours of work while others required making spreadsheets look pretty5,6,7--The Operations field trip I went on was really great and valuable--there should have been more that were not on Saturday but I understand the difficulty of competing with Silviculture.

This is the worst class I have ever taken in my entire life!!! My comments are for Chad Oliver's "managing resources" half only, Mike Ferrucci's forest ops class is very valuable and should remain in the curriculum as it's own class. In fact, mike should also teach a wildlife management course. Chad, on the other hand, should not be teaching at all. There was no organization of the class. Students had no idea what was expected of them, and had to keep asking each other just to be met with mutual bewilderment and eye rolling at the complete ridiculous waste of time we were being put through. The lectures were rambling stories with no frame of reference that we're impossible to extract information from. Despite the clear syllabus, none of the listed topics or skills were taught. The required exercises had unintelligible and incomplete instructions for that amounted to tedious, out-of-date busy work. Chad's TA was awful and unwilling to help or make herself available to help with the exercises that any student would need hours of help with. She did not attend any of the classes to interpret Chad for the students either or help with any of the class organization. But it doesn't matter, because this class is beyond the help of a good TA! (Mike's TA Tommie was great, by the way)!So to conclude, this class should cease to exist, period. It was a colossal waste of time, and caused a great deal of stress. I want my money back!! The administration has failed it's students horribly. The worst part of all is that most of the students only took this class fulfill a requirement. Any other elective would have been better. This does not belong in an accredited degree program. I think Chad Oliver is a very valuable asset to FES in many ways, for example through independent study, but NOT a structured class.

The course had two instructors. I found the operations component to be very helpful and relevant for students pursuing Forestry degrees. The management component has the potential to be helpful over the longterm, however, it would be more beneficial if organized better. Particularly, the forest modeling/inventory (LMS, FVS) was a bit clunky and inaccessible. If more emphasis and organization were placed on fewer cases it would greatly help.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects were the field trips and the combination of both Forest Ops and Managing Resources.
The exercises and the project.

My comments from now on will only focus on Mike Ferruci's section of the course, as I have already expressed my intense frustration about the design and delivery of the Managing Resources section of the course.The best aspects of Mike Ferucci's course were the field trips. I participated in the Spooner Hill exercise as well as the forest harvest plan component. Mike is always well organized, asks students to think critically, and is very open to feedback and questions. I learned a lot overall and would not hesitate to take another class with Mike.

Anything done with Mike Ferrucci. He knows his material, has the experience, and is very helpful. He's clearly here for the students and does all he can to make sure we have a great learning experience.
Operational field trips.Harvest planning.
group project- I learned a lot from other teammate
The insights are really valuable as are the exercises. I really enjoyed it.
The fieldtrips were great!
Covered a lot of topics that is hard to find in a single course.
The need for trade off and uncertainty analysis in decision making, readings were insightful as well as forestry field trips
logging operations course material was useful for forestry students, but was limited
Anything MIke Ferrucci did was educational and easy to understand/apply. Writing the harvest plan was incredibly helpful.
Field trips and client-based projects with Mike Ferrucci and the Quiet Corner Initiative were valuable experiences.

Working through the 66 example questions for the final--I googled most answers because the content was not present in the lectures (and the power points were mostly pictures with no words or explanations), however, I think I learned the most from going through those questions--just a pity that it couldn't have been actually taught during the pointless lectures I diligently attended...
The forest operations were well suited for forest management students. Guest lecturers were also very interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The field trips were great and were directly relevant to the course. However, presentations on the field trip material seemed to reduce the amount of time there was for the Managing Resources Section. It would have been nice of there was time to do some of the exercises (Excel Toggle, LMS) in class with the professor but because of the divided amount of time between the two professors, it was not possible to spend an entire class just learning to do the exercises.
The flow of the materials should be improved. It was pretty difficult for me to understand the material because of the collaboration between the managing resources and forest operation.
I think Forest Operations should be a separate course so that there is more time to actually dig into the material, do more field trips, etc.
The organization of the lectures is beyond confusing. I did not learn much in regards to the "managing resources" portion of this. A new instructor would significantly improve this.

The course was completely disorganize. Students typically hadno idea what was going on. Often I would leave a lecture with no idea what I was supposed to take home from it or how it applied to anything I was interested in.The course assignments, with the exception of operations, were an absolute waste of time. They were mostly irrelevant or so poorly presented that students were left extremely frustrated. The assignments require MAJOR revisions if they are to be anything but a waste of time.
Coordination between two lectures

The lectures across the board were terrible. The management lectures were absurd, and the operations lectures were slow, repetitive, and only moderately engaging. I think that Mike Ferrucci would do a much, much better job teaching on his own.
Lecture organization, and more field trips.

logging operations component needs more time - if we dont have time to go the field to see operations, we could at least spend time watching videos with the narration of the instructormanaging resources component was impractical - maybe a useful overview for an undergrad course but not useful material for grad level

Chad Oliver needs to stop teaching. While he may have been a leader in the field in past decades and his experience would be valuable in other settings, his teaching style and course content no longer resonate with students. Managing Resources and Forest Operations should absolutely without a doubt be two separate classes. It was a massive mistake to combine them. I spent a total of four hours outside of class working on the Managing Resources portion of the class. It is insulting to me that Yale allows students to waste their time and earn credit for a class that required next to no work. The course expectations were unclear from the start of the class, to the point that during finals week students still had no idea if they had completed enough assignments. I must repeat from other comments, however, that Mike's part of the class did well with the time/space it was given.

Anything that Chad Oliver did was of little or no practical use. His lectures were scattered and poor, and the projects were ill-conceived and had little value for learning. My time would've been much better-spent doing literally anything else.

All of it--the exercises were useful but were not connected to anything in the lectures (and vice versa)The Operations section should have been given equal time as the Managing Resources section. The two classes have great potential to be blended, so if they continue to be co-taught I think the class needs a serious overhaul and redevelopment to make that blending happen!Managing Resources had great potential to be logical--the Four levels of Management (Operations, Tactical, Strategic, and Policy) could have been explored more explicitly and in depth while also examining each within the six styles of Management (Exploitation, Preservationâ¦)

The management exercises could be better executed. Mainly, the exercises would benefit from organization. I would suggest to focus on fewer exercises and partition them so that students could get feedback as they progress through the exercises for improvement and understanding. Also, more information on the operations component would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes.
There were no labs or sections.
Good- lectures came before fieldtrips that supported what we learned in class.
Course lectures were effective
managing resources readings and assignments were lost - it was unclear how these were related to the trajectory of the course
Ferrucci's lectures and field trips matched up well. Oliver's assignments seemed irrelevant to the lectures he gave.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Initially, the course was perfect to do a little bit of both classes but towards the end it felt like it was better suited for MFs and less for MEMs

I took Mike's course because I thought it would be helpful in better understanding how to create forest harvest plans and how to think more critically about costs associated with different forest operations.
In theory, the "managing resources" portion would be very applicable to my MF degree. Unfortunately, it was not organized and did not make sense in class. I learned very little .

This course could have been REALLY been extremely useful if the original course outline had been presented in a structured manner. The course concept is great but what was presented and the way it was presented was next to worthless.

Very necessary class, but it needs a more practical component as mentioned above. We would be learning about how to manage timber sales from start to end in addition to equip. There is plenty of time for this in the semester.
It made me appreciate the broader implication of my thesis research and the importance of making it available to society
I see how Forest Operations fits, but I am still confused as to where Managing Resources was supposed to fit in. It baffles me as to why it is required for MFs.
I don't know that this course fits into my overall academic program in any way.
I think there is potential for this class to be extremely useful for the MF, MESc and other areas of focus, however as it is taught now I got very very little out of it.

The course is designed to prepare students both for careers in forest management and as forest practitioners (particularly field foresters). While I think the topics covered in this course are worthwhile, the perspective is so broad that it may need to be focused more narrowly. Forest operations, forest modeling, and forest management could each be stand alone classes.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn on how to manage the resources.
Same answer as above.

I really liked the course outline...it hit on a little bit of everything that managers need to know. I was looking forward to seeing management at several levels: planning, strategic, tactical, and operational. Unfortunately, the course was so poorly organized and presented that I did not get much from it.
to gain more useful skills related to forestry operation
Pretty much required and filled buckets on the green sheet.
For the management skills.
I needed to learn about resources management strategies and forest operations
It is required.
I thought I would learn something about managing finite and renewable resources.
It fulfilled two of the MF requirements for which there is basically no alternative
It is required for my degree

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I thought the Managing Resources Section met my expectations and the field trips exceeded my expectations.
Yes
From the perspective of Mike Ferucci's course, mostly. I think it would have been great to have the full course (separate from Managing Resources), because he had to cut a lot of material.
No
Definitely not. The course left me extremely frustrated and disappointed in the education quality offered at FES and how nothing has been done to improve this potentially valuable course.
yes
No- it missed many operational pieces and the management side was a waste of time.
yes
Yes
no - logging operations did not go into enough detail, and resource mgmt was a waste of time - just a simple overview of undergrad level sustainability
No.

Not at all. I gained some forestry skills but that was an added bonus. In terms of actually learning about how resources are managed, I feel like I don't know any more than I did the day I first walked into the course.
No

The knowledge/skills did not meet my expectations. Because of the broad perspective of the course, the subjects seemed "watered down." With some revision to the course I think it could achieve my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Great team work!
It was very valuab.le for me to work in a project together in a group because I was able to learn from the other perspectives and enriched my own knowledge through the discussion processes

I thought the group work went pretty smoothly; it would have been helpful, however, to have the field day closer to the middle, not the end of the semester. It was challenging to meet with my group during the end of the semester when everyone was scrambling.

There was an extraordinary amount of free-riding occurring during group work projects. The assignments were shouldered by students who cared about doing a good job even if they got very little out of it while others were comfortable with letting them do it.The harvest plans should be done individually. Not doing so, left all the work to a few while some students learned absolutely nothing.
there was no disadvantages, I learned more than my expectation
The group harvest plan was one of the best parts of the class.
We were able to share ideas and perspectives on a number of topics.
I learned a lot from classmates. It was difficult to find students with common study interest
group work was good - it allowed indepth analysis into a topic of our choosing
Doing the harvest plan as a group was valuable--I learned a lot from my more experienced classmates.
It went well, but clearer expectations would have helped alleviate some of the conflicts and struggles that we endured.

The advantages were that we could complain about the assignment and course together, and that I alone did not have to spend 20+ hours working on exercises and the final.Group work is always valuable in the abstract--team work, self discovery, idea sharing...

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You will gain more than what you expected if you do the exercises and the project.

For Chad's section of the course: I would say figure out your own project and pitch it to Chad very early on.For Mike's section of the course: I would suggest that people participate in the forest harvest plan exercise, as it's a great way to integrate a lot of the material from the course. I would also suggest students go on the southern forest field trip to complement the course (I believe this was an option in prior years, to get an extra credit for field operations).
Do not take this.

If you are a MF, take operations with Professor Ferrucci. If it is not offered independent of Managing Resources, think very carefully about the decision.Professor Oliver's class sounds great but is terribly DISAPPOINTING. Unless he puts more time into his lectures and the quality/relevance of the material he presents...don't take his class.
Do project instead of doing all excercises
Get a really good independent project lined up prior to the class. Dr. Oliver is great to work with on these ind. projects- he's enthusiastic, knowledgable and very supportive.
Do the readings before class, and take advantage of office hours.
Every student concerned with natural resources must take this course
needs to be broken into 2 components, and resource mgmt course needs re-focus
Wait until these classes are separated--otherwise avoid at all costs. With that said, I highly recommend the Forest Ops piece of the class once it is a stand-alone class.
Take Mike's course, you'll learn a lot. Ignore Chad, you'll just get confused.

Get started on the Exercises early if that is the route you choose to go. If you don't want to do exercises then pick an Operations project or your own.Don't worry about the lectures unless they change the structure of the course
Don't take managing resources

I would suggest to meet with the instructors frequently to solidify what is required for projects etc. Choose few exercises to explore more thoroughly. And, the operations field exercises are great learning experiences.
